@nikkilouh Yet not viewed or considered #weMHNs

The support an active community could bring to #homelessness #mentalhealth is immeasurable

3. We cant account for Seeing a young woman #homeless and suffering #mentalhealth and #addiction be told by someone purporting to support people as a #citizen that she wouldn't get help at any service....two days later she was found dead in a tent #WeMHNs
But some outcomes we cant account for #weMHNs

And to hear another human state they "dont care to live with a roof over my head as long as i can see the stars....that's when i feel safe" is  a sign that something is failing and we struggle if they dont conform #weMHNs

I get that we sometimes find #homelessness difficult...maybe we fear it could so easily be us? Its rarely in isolation though and coexists with a whole host of other issues and ills and #mentalhealth is just one #weMHNs
@CanopyMarie @VanessaRNMH Ah but should we need one? #weMHNs

The one thing i did learn from Tent City was that the system....no matter how loaded...can be changed cos we did it #weMHNs

@RaiWaddingham it's time to rethink. Researchers usually look from the outside in, about things we get curious about....the questionnaires people use are fundamentally flawed and limiting, today's research is based on previous research which was most likely flawed.
@hearingvoice

@aldersonday many people carry the experience of voice hearing without wanting or needing to talk about it to others. We need to understand what might bring a person to a place where they do need help. The times when we might all become overwhelmed. 
@hearingvoice

@JasonPoolej2 making space for madness, pointing out that spaces where people are brought for healing might be experiencing the space as anti-life. We need to listen, can we overcome the territorialisation of spaces for care and assist people to live with vitality.
@hearingvoice

RT @UniOfHullOnline: @alzheimerssoc We agree! üòä We asked carers what helps them to live well with dementia - here are the top 9 üëá #Dementia‚Ä¶

Delirium
What works:
Care passports/This Is Me
Liaison working
Create emergency care and end of life plans
Appreciating levels of care available
Joined up work including discharge planning
Pain management should be planned
#yhdementia
@YHSCN_MHDN
@psychinformatic

Delirium
Challenges for the individual and their family:
Need to be included in decision making
Lack of advocacy
Need key carer to be heard
#yhdementia
@YHSCN_MHDN

Delirium
Challenges for services:
Person isn't known
Communication is difficult
Services operate in silos
#yhdementia
@YHSCN_MHDN

WORKSHOP B Delirium
Tees, Esk and Wear Valleys team.
Considering challenges for services, for individuals and their families in relation to our casestudy.
#yhdementia
@YHSCN_MHDN

Challenges for services
Knowing who is responsible, difficulty accessing professionals, person with dementia not known when passed from service to service, inadequate information sharing including risk information.
#yhdementia
@YHSCN_MHDN

#yhdementia
Workshop A
From home to care home 1, to acute hospital, to care home 2, to mental health unit, to nursing home to secure unit for one day, then to mental health unit. Demonstrating the number of transitions a person might have to manage.
@YHSCN_MHDN

Workshop A
Emma Wolverson, Clinical Psychologist and Jo Inglis, Charge Nurse, Maister Lodge, Hull, are presenting a casestudy from an inpatient mental health unit focusing on transitions.
#yhdementia
@YHSCN_MHDN

People with dementia have a 13-22% higher risk of developing delerium.
Ask.. Are they different today? 
Sudden confusion, agitation or sleepiness might be signs of delerium.
Use the Delerium Wheel to help identify and stop delerium. 
#yhdementia
@YHSCN_MHDN
@psychinformatic

DELIRIUM kills
Suspect it
Spot it
Stop it
#deliriumready
#Icanpreventdelirium
#yhdementia
@YHSCN_MHDN
@psychinformatic

A key issue for nurses and support workers is ensuring they are able to articulate what they are doing in order to have a shared language....recognising our own skills sets...
#yhdementia

Ian's team is based in Newcastle, there are teams across three localities with a variety of professionals represented, including nurses, occupational therapists and psychologists plus some sessional psychiatry input.
#yhdementia

8 Fundamental Needs- helps staff consider how the activity undertaken is a vehicle to meet needs and reduce distress. This list can also be used to help consider behaviours at any point without full formulation. 
#yhdementia

Training doesn't always result in positive change, watching staff revealed that nurses and support workers know more than they might communicate.... Model for key Communication Skills developed.
#yhdementia

There's an inpatient unit in Cumbria which doesn't have a psychiatrist...interesting...watch this space!
#yhdementia

People with dementia overthink....of course a psychological approach can help, we must try to understand the person with dementia's thinking. Then we must understand what staff are thinking...carers must be a focus. 
#yhdementia

Formulation... A narrative that binds people together in their understanding of the problem.
#yhdementia

We need to collect relevant info, pull it together in a meaningful way and look for ways to interrupt the I wanted pattern of behaviour.
#yhdementia
We can't replace medication with 'a thing' , it's an approach that's needed. #yhdementia

What we call experiences can take us down a particular route to medication or therapy.....looking at behaviour rather than investigating the cause has often led to reliance upon medication.
